and that of the Institutio Oratorio an argument for the theory that Quintilian must have been the author, not Tacitus. But exclusive atten-

tion to this resemblance, even though it extends in several passages to thought and substance as well as to forms of expression, is very apt to mislead,¹ especially when it is overdone. A safer method is to compare Tacitus, not with Quintilian, but with himself. The theory of a con- tinuous development of his style through his various writings has been worked out by Wolfflin (Philologus, xxv, pp. 9²·134) and other scholars ¹3 and numerous arguments in proof of the authorship of Tacitus may now be drawn from the very source which formerly supplied antagonistic critics with their most trusted weapons.

In the first place it must be repeated that, on the theory that the Dialogtu was the work of the historian’s youth, it seems to have been a natural and appropriate outcome of the studies in which that youth is known to have been trained. The early bent of a student iu those days was generally towards rhetoric and the art of public speaking. This was the broadest avenue to public life at Rome, and Tacitus may have followed it from motivas of general conformity as well as from private and persona} choice. But his genius must have felt a strong affinity for the art which, iu the perfection which it had attained to under the republic, stands now for us as one of the symbols of his country’s great- ness. We know that he gained high distinction as an orator iu the earlier part of his career. The younger Pliny, who was only some six or seven years his junior, has left it ou record that his friend and corre· spondent had aheady established a great reputation (cum tom tu soma gloriaque floreres, vii. ao, 4), when he himself was just entering public life. And even alter Tacitus had retired from the profession of an advocate, his funeral eulogy of Verginius Rufus (nn. 97) gave proof of his great gift of eloquence²; while his official prosecution, coniointly with Pliny, of Marius Priscus proconsul of Africa (in roo an.) evidently produced on his colleague that impression of elevation and dignity which no reader can fail to carry away from the study of the historian's works ⁸.
